nodes.name: Meta
nodes.Notes: Formerly Facebook Inc.; major hyperscale datacenter operator; founding contributor to Open Compute Project

nodes.name: Google
nodes.Notes: Part of Alphabet Inc.; known for high-density datacenter designs and early adoption of liquid cooling

nodes.name: Microsoft
nodes.Notes: Hyperscale operator building massive AI-focused cloud infrastructure

nodes.name: Amazon
nodes.Notes: Hyperscale operator with large cloud computing footprint

nodes.name: Nvidia
nodes.Notes: Dominant AI GPU supplier; drives datacenter power/cooling requirements with new architectures (Blackwell, GB200)

nodes.name: AMD
nodes.Notes: Competes in AI accelerators (MI300) and general GPU/CPU markets

nodes.name: Intel
nodes.Notes: Major CPU supplier; also invests in AI accelerators

nodes.name: Mellanox
nodes.Notes: Acquired by Nvidia in 2020

nodes.name: Schneider Electric
nodes.Notes: Owns APC; partners with Nvidia on AI-ready liquid-cooled reference designs

nodes.name: Vertiv
nodes.Notes: Formerly Emerson Network Power; supplies UPS, busway, cooling solutions

nodes.name: Eaton
nodes.Notes: Focuses on electrical distribution and backup for datacenters; acquired Tripp Lite

nodes.name: Legrand
nodes.Notes: Owns Starline busway, Raritan & Server Tech (intelligent rack PDUs), Minkels (racks)

nodes.name: Digital Realty
nodes.Notes: Major global datacenter operator, often uses modular expansions

nodes.name: Equinix
nodes.Notes: Focus on network exchange points and multi-tenant datacenters

nodes.name: Emerson Electric
nodes.Notes: Former parent of Emerson Network Power (spun off as Vertiv)

nodes.name: Emerson Network Power
nodes.Notes: Spun off from Emerson Electric and renamed Vertiv in 2016

nodes.name: Platinum Equity
nodes.Notes: Acquired Emerson Network Power in 2016, rebranded it as Vertiv

nodes.name: Liebert
nodes.Notes: Pioneer in UPS/CRAC systems; part of Vertiv (formerly Emerson Network Power)

nodes.name: Avocent
nodes.Notes: Acquired by Emerson; known for KVM & datacenter management software; now part of Vertiv

nodes.name: APC
nodes.Notes: American Power Conversion; acquired by Schneider Electric in 2007

nodes.name: Mark Zuckerberg
nodes.Notes: Co-founder of Facebook (Meta)

nodes.name: Open Compute Project (OCP)
nodes.Notes: Founded by Facebook, Intel, Rackspace, etc. to share open-source hardware designs

nodes.name: Blackwell
nodes.Notes: Nvidia's next-generation GPU architecture, driving higher rack power densities

nodes.name: GB200
nodes.Notes: Nvidia Grace-Blackwell GPU family; ~130 kW per rack with direct liquid cooling

nodes.name: Liquid Cooling
nodes.Notes: Direct-to-chip cold plate approach required for high-density AI servers

nodes.name: AI Datacenter
nodes.Notes: Facilities optimized for AI compute; higher power densities, advanced cooling

nodes.name: DGX GH200
nodes.Notes: Nvidia's AI server platform combining Grace CPU + Hopper GPU

nodes.name: Grace Hopper Superchips (GH200)
nodes.Notes: Nvidia's hybrid CPU-GPU modules preceding the Grace-Blackwell line

nodes.name: NVLink
nodes.Notes: Nvidia's high-speed GPU-to-GPU interconnect

nodes.name: NVLink Switch
nodes.Notes: Nvidia's fabric switch for linking multiple GPUs in a cluster

nodes.name: DGX SuperPOD
nodes.Notes: Reference architecture for multi-rack Nvidia GPU clusters

nodes.name: Open Accelerator Module (OAM)
nodes.Notes: OCP standard for pluggable AI accelerator cards

nodes.name: SLA
nodes.Notes: Service Level Agreement measured in availability (e.g., 99.9% vs 99.999%)

nodes.name: Hyperscaler
nodes.Notes: Operators like Meta, Google, Microsoft, Amazon running 50–100+ MW data centers

nodes.name: PUE
nodes.Notes: Power Usage Effectiveness; total facility power / IT load power

nodes.name: Tier Classification
nodes.Notes: Uptime Institute Tier I–IV describing data center redundancy and reliability

nodes.name: Generators
nodes.Notes: Diesel or gas gensets for backup power in datacenters; arranged in N+1 or 2N

nodes.name: Gigawatt Clusters
nodes.Notes: Massive AI compute deployments approaching 1 GW or more across multiple sites

nodes.name: N+1
nodes.Notes: One extra unit beyond the base (N) needed; ensures concurrent maintainability

nodes.name: 2N
nodes.Notes: Fully duplicated power/cooling systems; allows fault tolerance

nodes.name: Fault Tolerance
nodes.Notes: Ability for data center to operate despite component failures (Tier IV requirement)

nodes.name: Machine Learning
nodes.Notes: Uses GPUs and other accelerators; driving AI datacenter scale-up

nodes.name: GPU
nodes.Notes: Graphics Processing Unit; essential for AI training and inference

nodes.name: PSU
nodes.Notes: Power Supply Unit; converts AC to DC for servers

nodes.name: Busway
nodes.Notes: Enclosed busbar trunk system for distributing power overhead to racks

nodes.name: BBU
nodes.Notes: Battery Backup Unit at rack level; eliminates need for central UPS in OCP designs

nodes.name: VRM
nodes.Notes: Voltage Regulator Module on server boards; steps down to CPU/GPU core voltages

nodes.name: CRAC
nodes.Notes: Computer Room Air Conditioning; legacy air-cooling units in data centers

nodes.name: PDU
nodes.Notes: Power Distribution Unit; distributes and monitors power to racks

nodes.name: DCIM
nodes.Notes: Data Center Infrastructure Management software for power/cooling/space monitoring

nodes.name: Static Transfer Switch (STS)
nodes.Notes: Electronic device allowing rapid load transfer between two AC sources

nodes.name: DGX GB200 NVL72
nodes.Notes: Rack-scale system with 72 Blackwell GPUs drawing ~130 kW, liquid-cooled

relationships.details: Co-founded Facebook (Meta) in 2004
Next-gen GPU architecture for high-power AI workloads
Grace-Blackwell Superchips enabling ~130 kW per rack with liquid cooling
Adopted advanced cooling for AI hardware (TPUs) before Nvidia
Initially slow to adopt but now mandates direct liquid cooling for new GPUs
Meta (Facebook) open-sourced hardware designs in 2011 to launch OCP
Nvidia acquired Mellanox in 2020 for high-speed networking
Spun off from Emerson Electric and renamed Vertiv in 2016
Emerson Network Power was part of Emerson Electric before spin-off
Private equity firm purchase leading to Vertiv's creation
APC was acquired by Schneider Electric in 2007
Rack-scale AI server with Grace CPU + Hopper GPU generation
Reference design for large-scale GPU clusters
Used for dense GPU interconnects in AI clusters
Operates massive global datacenter campuses pivoting to AI
Highly dense facilities, above 40 kW/rack for AI
Building Azure facilities for large-scale AI clusters
AWS runs AI/ML instances in massive cloud datacenters
UPS, busway, CRAC units, modular power systems
Galaxy UPS line, reference designs for AI liquid cooling, switchgear
UPS, switchgear, battery solutions for data centers
Starline overhead power distribution and Raritan/Server Tech PDUs
Redesigning data centers to accommodate new Nvidia GPUs
High-density AI gear demands direct-to-chip water cooling
Power density too high for air alone
Up to 130 kW per rack, mandated by Nvidia
Sells AI GPUs to large cloud operators
Hyperscalers run huge facilities to meet AI demand
Soaring demand for model training/inference forces new builds
GPUs accelerate ML training and inference
Market leader in AI accelerator GPUs
Competes in GPU and AI acceleration
Compete in hyperscale AI capabilities and data center design
Hyperscalers vying for AI and cloud dominance
Azure vs. AWS in cloud and AI markets
A 72-GPU system with ~130 kW per rack, fully liquid-cooled
